title: Neuronal Signaling & Synaptic Transmission
description: Understand how neurons generate, propagate, and transmit electrical signals — the cellular basis of all nervous system function.
learningObjectives: Describe the structural compartments of a neuron and their functional roles
Explain the ionic basis of the resting membrane potential
Trace the sequence of events during an action potential
Describe the molecular steps of synaptic transmission at chemical synapses
Identify major neurotransmitter systems and their roles in brain function

sections.title: The Neuron: Structure and Functional Compartments
sections.content: The neuron is the fundamental signaling unit of the nervous system, specialized for receiving, integrating, and transmitting electrochemical information. Despite enormous morphological diversity, all neurons share core structural features optimized for long-distance communication.
keyPoints: Soma (cell body): contains the nucleus and most organelles; the primary site of protein synthesis and metabolic activity
Dendrites: highly branched extensions that receive synaptic inputs; dendritic spines dramatically increase surface area
Axon: a single elongated process that conducts output signals away from the soma toward synaptic terminals
Myelin sheath: lipid-rich insulation produced by oligodendrocytes (CNS) or Schwann cells (PNS); enables rapid saltatory conduction

sections.title: The Resting Membrane Potential
sections.content: At rest, neurons maintain a stable voltage difference across their plasma membrane — the resting membrane potential — of approximately −70 mV (inside negative). This potential arises from the unequal distribution of ions across the membrane and the selective permeability of leak channels at rest.
keyPoints: Key ions: Na⁺ (high extracellular), K⁺ (high intracellular), Cl⁻ (high extracellular), large organic anions (intracellular)
Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase: actively pumps 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ in per ATP, maintaining ion gradients
At rest, membrane permeability is dominated by K⁺ leak channels; K⁺ efflux makes the interior negative
The Nernst equation calculates the equilibrium potential for a single ion; the Goldman equation integrates all permeabilities

sections.title: The Action Potential
sections.content: An action potential (AP) is a rapid, all-or-none reversal of membrane potential that propagates along the axon without loss of amplitude. It is triggered when a depolarizing stimulus brings the membrane to threshold (~−55 mV) and involves the sequential activation of voltage-gated ion channels.
keyPoints: Depolarization: voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open → Na⁺ rushes in → membrane potential surges to ~+40 mV
Repolarization: Na⁺ channels inactivate; delayed voltage-gated K⁺ channels open → K⁺ flows out → potential falls
Hyperpolarization (undershoot): K⁺ channels close slowly, driving the membrane briefly below resting potential
Refractory period: absolute (Na⁺ channels inactivated, no AP possible) and relative (threshold elevated), ensuring unidirectional propagation

sections.title: Synaptic Transmission
sections.content: Neurons communicate predominantly at synapses — specialized junctions that convert an electrical signal into a chemical signal and back. Chemical synaptic transmission involves precise molecular machinery at both the presynaptic terminal and the postsynaptic membrane.
keyPoints: AP arrives at axon terminal → depolarization opens voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels → Ca²⁺ floods into the terminal
Ca²⁺ triggers SNARE protein-mediated fusion of synaptic vesicles with the plasma membrane (exocytosis)
Neurotransmitters diffuse across the synaptic cleft (~20 nm) and bind receptors on the postsynaptic membrane
Ionotropic receptors: ligand-gated ion channels (fast, ms timescale); Metabotropic receptors: G-protein coupled (slow, modulatory)

sections.title: Major Neurotransmitter Systems
sections.content: The brain uses a diverse chemical vocabulary of neurotransmitters, each with defined synthesis pathways, receptor subtypes, and functional roles. Dysregulation of these systems underlies a wide spectrum of neurological and psychiatric disorders.
keyPoints: Glutamate: primary excitatory transmitter in the CNS; AMPA receptors mediate fast excitation; NMDA receptors are critical for synaptic plasticity and memory
GABA: primary inhibitory transmitter; GABA-A receptors are Cl⁻ channels (fast inhibition); target of benzodiazepines and anesthetics
Dopamine: reward, motivation, and motor control; degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra causes Parkinson's disease
Serotonin (5-HT): regulates mood, sleep, and appetite; selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are first-line antidepressants

quiz.question: Which ion movement is primarily responsible for establishing the resting membrane potential of ~−70 mV?
options: Na⁺ leaking into the cell through voltage-gated channels
Ca²⁺ leaking into the cell through leak channels
K⁺ leaking out of the cell through K⁺ leak channels
Cl⁻ leaking into the cell through GABA-A receptors
quiz.explanation: At rest, the neuronal membrane is most permeable to K⁺ via K⁺ leak channels. Since K⁺ is highly concentrated inside the cell, it diffuses outward down its concentration gradient, making the interior electrically negative (approximately −70 mV).

quiz.question: During the depolarization phase of an action potential, which ion enters the cell and through which channel type?
options: K⁺ through voltage-gated K⁺ channels
Na⁺ through voltage-gated Na⁺ channels
Ca²⁺ through ligand-gated Ca²⁺ channels
Cl⁻ through voltage-gated Cl⁻ channels
quiz.explanation: When the membrane reaches threshold, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open rapidly. Na⁺ rushes into the cell down its steep electrochemical gradient, causing a rapid depolarization to approximately +40 mV.

quiz.question: What is the primary function of the myelin sheath around axons?
options: To synthesize and store neurotransmitters
To provide direct metabolic energy (ATP) to the axon
To increase the speed of action potential propagation via saltatory conduction
To prevent voltage-gated Na⁺ channels from opening
quiz.explanation: Myelin acts as electrical insulation, forcing action potentials to 'jump' between exposed nodes of Ranvier — a process called saltatory conduction. This dramatically increases conduction velocity while reducing metabolic cost.

quiz.question: Which ion channel opening is the critical trigger for neurotransmitter release at the presynaptic terminal?
options: Voltage-gated Na⁺ channels
Voltage-gated K⁺ channels
Voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels
Ligand-gated AMPA receptors
quiz.explanation: When an action potential depolarizes the presynaptic terminal, voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels open. The resulting Ca²⁺ influx is the essential trigger for SNARE-protein-mediated fusion of synaptic vesicles and exocytosis of neurotransmitter.

quiz.question: How does activation of GABA-A receptors inhibit neuronal firing?
options: By blocking voltage-gated Na⁺ channels directly
By opening Cl⁻ channels, causing Cl⁻ influx that hyperpolarizes the membrane
By activating Gi proteins that reduce intracellular cAMP levels
By triggering K⁺ efflux through NMDA receptors
quiz.explanation: GABA-A receptors are ionotropic Cl⁻ channels. When GABA binds, Cl⁻ flows into the neuron (because its equilibrium potential is typically more negative than the resting potential), hyperpolarizing the membrane and reducing the probability of reaching action potential threshold.
